ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

LAND ACQUISITION
(Differences in valuations and rates of compensation)


    1. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Law and the Environment what is the reason for the difference in the rates of compensation and valuation in respect of land in the same locality acquired by different Government departments and statutory boards; how land to be acquired is valued, and why some of the cases have been referred to the courts resulting in an increase in compensation; and if his Ministry will consider setting up a committee to regularise the valuation of land to be acquired by Government departments and statutory boards.

Column: 620



    The Minister for Law and the Environment (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, differences in valuations and the rates of compensation payable in respect of lands in the same locality, arise mainly because no two parcels of land are identical in all respects. Each parcel of land has its own characteristics depending on the tenure, Master Plan zoning, state of encumbrances, physical characteristics, the improvements thereon and accessibility to services. All these factors affect market value. Moreover, valuation is not an exact science and there is considerable scope for variations in opinions between valuers.

    Under the provisions of section 23 of the Land Acquisition Act, a claimant is entitled to appeal to the Appeals Board, which is presided over by a High Court Judge, against the Collector's award, if he feels that the compensation is inadequate. Under section

Column: 621

35 of the Act, the Appeals Board shall not reduce the amount awarded by the Collector, but may increase it.

    Centralising valuations has been considered and rejected. The Management Services Department of the Ministry of Finance considered that setting up a central Acquisition Division to conduct compulsory land acquisitions in contradiction to the present practice of close consultation between valuers serving in Government or statutory boards would, on balance, be a retrogressive step.

    The Member will be aware of the provisions of sections 33 to 34 of the Land Acquisition Act (Cap. 272), which sets out the matters to be considered as well as those to be disregarded in determining compensation payable for lands compulsorily acquired. The concept of market value is used as the basis for compensation. When assessing the amount of compensation, Collectors are required to take into consideration the market value of the land as at the date of publication of the declaration of acquisition, or the 30th day of November, 1973, whichever is the lower.

JURONG TOWN CORPORATION
(Decline in land area taken up by industrialists)


    2. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Finance if he will ascertain from the Jurong Town Corporation (a) the reason for the decline in land area in Jurong taken up by the applicants in 1975 as compared with 1974, as stated in the Economic Survey of Singapore. 1975, and whether smaller areas of land are being taken up by applicants because of the increase of rates in the leasing of land by the Corporation; (b) of the 122 applicants for land in Jurong in 1975, how many of them are companies owned by Singapore citizens and how many are joint ventures with foreign investors: and (c) what are the different rates in the leasing of land in the various industrial estates from 1973 to 1975.

Column: 622



    The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, the decline in the area of land taken up by industrialists in Jurong and other industrial estates was due mainly to the generally depressed economic conditions prevailing in 1975. There is no reason to believe that the decline in the total area leased and comparatively smaller lots taken up were due to the increase in the land rent charged by JTC. JTC has increased the land rent from 1 8 cents per square foot per year in 1974 to 24 cents per square foot per year in 1975 due to the steep rise in land and development costs These rates are, however, still well below the prevailing market mates for private industrial land. Smaller lots of land were taken up because there were fewer large foreign investors who normally take up larger areas of land.

    Out of the 122 allocations of industrial land made in Jurong in 1975. 58 were to companies owned by Singapore citizens, 24 to joint venture companies with foreign investors and 40 to foreign companies.

    Mr Yeo Toon Chia (Kampong Kapor): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask what are the determining factors in granting a lease of, say. 10 years. 20 years or 30 years? Does it depend on the amount of capital invested and the type of industry? Can the Minister enlighten us on this?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, I am not entirely familiar with the present practice of the Jurong Town Corporation. But as I understand from its practices in the past, they were dependent on the nature of the industry and the duration of the return on the

Column: 623

capital required. If it was a relatively heavy investment, then a longer period would obviously be required. There were also other considerations, such as the relationship to the sea As there was a shortage of land along the sea-front, shorter leases were granted for investments in areas near the sea.

JURONG COUNTRY CLUB
(Particulars)


    3. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Finance if he will ascertain from the Jurong Town Corporation (i) the total cost of construction of the Jurong Country Club; (ii) the cost of maintaining the Club and whether the subscriptions from members are sufficient for its maintenance; (iii) the entrance fee and subscription for membership of the Club and the present number of members; and (iv) whether membership is open to the public or, if restricted, what are the conditions for membership.

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am given to understand that the total cost of developing the Jurong Country Club amounted to $2.917 million as at the end of 1975. Another $230,000 would be required to complete the development this year.

    For the first seven months of operation from June 1 975. the cost of maintaining the Club, including depreciation on fixed assets, amounted to $410,000. When the second 9-hole course and other facilities are ready, the cost of maintenance is expected to increase to 5520.000 per year.

    Entrance fee is $3,000 for ordinary members and $12,000 for corporate members. Subscription is $25 per, member per month. The Club now has 810 members.

    Income from subscriptions, together with other sources of fund, such as green fees, rental from practice range and rental of tennis courts and restaurants will be sufficient to cover the cost of maintenance when membership is increased further by

Column: 624

780 members. The Club, when completed with more facilities for members, should be able to break even in 1 977 and operate on its own steam thereafter. There would be no need for JTC to subsidise its operations.

    Membership is open to all Singapore citizens. Preference is, however, given to applicants who reside and/or work in Jurong Town. Permanent residents and non-Singapore citizens will also be considered if they live and/or work in Jurong Town or in one of the industrial estates managed by the Jurong Town Corporation.

    Mr Yeo Toon Chia: Sir, from tie reply given by the Minister, we can see that the entrance fee is rather high. Will the JTC consider reducing the entrance fee so that more people will be able to enjoy the facilities provided by the Jurong Country Club?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, I think the entrance fee has been fixed at a rate which would enable the Club to pay for itself as rapidly as possible. Of course, there is also the need to limit the number of members who use the facilities of the Club, otherwise every one will want to use its facilities.

    Mr Yeo Toon Chia: Sir, I am not happy with the Minister's reply. It costs about $3 million to construct the Club. I think we should try to allow more people to enjoy the facilities of a good club. Instead of limiting it, it should open its membership to more people. No doubt income from entrance fees will be reduced, but with a larger membership the total collection of fees will equalise the figure and it can still maintain the Club house.

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, I am not a golfer and I do not know the economics of running a golf course. But plain economics brings out the assumption that with an unlimited number of members the facilities will have to be shared by a greater number of people, and it is therefore very likely that instead of being able to play golf when you want to, you will have to play when you do not want to.

MAIN AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES OF SINGAPORE FOR THE

FINANCIAL YEAR 1ST APRIL, 1976 TO 31ST MARCH, 1977



    Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [4th Allotted Day]

2.43 p.m.

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



    Head Q --

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head Q be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead AAA 1004*. (* The same amendment also stood in the names of Messrs Teong Eng Siong, L.P. Rodrigo, Hwang Soo Jin. P. Govindaswamy, Ch'ng Jit Koon and Dr Chiang Hai Ding.)

    Mr Speaker, Sir, culturally we have always been conscious of our rich and varied heritage, and have expressed pride in our cultural diversity. The Ministry of Culture has given as much encouragement to the reflection of the variety of our cultural potential as limited financial allocations would allow. I think I must emphasise here "as limited financial allocations would allow". More recently we have had the development of such activities as Music for Everyone, Art for Everyone, Concert for the Young, and various exhibitions. But I think my point about financial allocations, and therefore constraint upon effort, may be illustrated.

    For example, in a Ministry whose avowed aim is nurturing and development of culture, there is only one cultural affairs officer. I understand he is assisted by a very small number of officers, perhaps two or three officers. The Minister may be able to enlighten us there. What can this small, even if gallant, handful of people do? How many cultural events have they been able to organise, and for how many people? Compare this number with what reasonable number would indicate an effective spread of influence of these cultural events. Such a kind of examination would serve as an indicator to show the extent to which we are

Column: 626

committed to a policy of encouraging cultural development.

2.45 p.m.

    There are other indicators. If we examine another item of expenditure we can get a good idea of how a policy is reflected in budget allocations. For example, for the promotion of cultural matters and exhibitions, there has been an increase of allocation from $65,000 for last year to $105,000 for this coming financial year, which (mind you) includes a sum of $30,000 that is subject to Treasury sanction, While the Minister for Culture is no doubt grateful for such small mercies, it would be interesting to find out what we are getting with this kind of money. Perhaps the Minister could tell us later.

    What appears to be happening in the case of the activities like Art for Everyone, and Concert for the Young, and so on, is that they seem to be organised on an ad hoc basis and this is because there is not very many staff to look after these events. Like when it is come to be known that some artistes are passing through, or when a local military band is available for some performance. There does not seem to be any sequential programme planned or any particular aim that is discernible in the arrangement of the events in such items as Music for Everyone and Concert for the Young, although one must admit that an idea like the Beautiful Singapore Art Exhibition does have a worthwhile theme.

    To take yet another illustration, if you look at the National Theatre Trust Annual Report for 1974-75, you will find that its first preoccupation is major renovations to the Theatre and expenditure. This kind of thing represents its principal problem. What else can the Trust do except what it has done, namely, enter into joint presentation with other organisations. All the same, with limited resources the Trust seems to have done well. But again its dependence on sponsors is a clue to the extent of official support for its work.

Column: 627



    An exceptional, important role as everybody knows is that played by broadcasting: perhaps, especially, by TV in respect of giving expression to cultural policies. In this regard, for further contribution to a sense of belonging, to a consciousness of community. TV has to turn to encouraging greater understanding among our citizens of one another's cultural forms. People have to be stimulated into a more heightened awareness of, and interest in the various characteristic forms of cultural expression. And the stimulus can be provided by RTS if it sets its mind to it and if it gets the support; if it is the policy to require it to do this kind of thing.

    However, just as an illustration, what is the position at present in terms of programmes that are viewed by a mixed viewership, by a multi-lingual viewership, by a viewership composed of audiences from the different language streams at the same time? I am just trying to illustrate a certain condition in our society. The programmes that get a multi-lingual viewership are the imported programmes, especially in English and mainly in the crime and violence. entertainment, and full-length film categories. And these programmes would perhaps occupy as much as half of TV time during a week. At the same time, one other programme that gets a mixed audience, a multi-lingual audience, is Justice Pao. Incidentally, this popularity of Justice Pao with a multi-lingual audience shows that a programme with a cultural flavour of one of the main cultural streams of our society can, can indeed, have an audience transcending a particular ethnic group. Unfortunately, here again. Justice Pao is also an imported programme.

    Mr Sim Boon Woo (Changi): Pao Piao.

    Mr Conceicao: Yes, we will come to Pao Piao. Otherwise, we do not seem to be able to break through beyond insular situations when one ethnic group is watching programmes only in its own language. Let me make it plain that it is good that

Column: 628

entertainment be provided for Tamils to watch Tamil cinema and Malays to watch Pesta Ria and Chinese to watch Pao Piao, but we want something in addition to this where their sights are taken beyond their own cultural boundaries. I hope that the Minister will not retort like he did the last time when I said the same thing, hsin p'ing, chit, chiu new bottles, old wine. I hope I got the pronunciation right. Culture is a laborious process of growth and points have to be reiterated in order to arouse adequate attention, especially as adequate attention does not seem to have been aroused previously.

    If I may make one last point that relates to our young people, we should think of providing them with more opportunities to continue the cultural interest they have developed in schools which have been encouraged by the Ministry of Education's Extra-Curricular Activities programmes, youth festivals, band competitions, and so on. I have also mentioned the view held by some young people themselves that not enough is done to set the sights of our young people beyond their immediate surroundings. In this connection, perhaps TV could produce programmes on ASEAN problems, matters, background and other regional themes, gradually extending the focus in a more global direction. We, of course, have Newsreel but the shots of Newsreel comprise mere flashes and there is no depth analysis of events that take place around us. We have thought and talked about the necessity to carry the attention of our young people beyond their immediate preoccupations. Perhaps our organisation has not arrived at a standard when we can produce programmes like Panorama and 24 Hours that I have noticed, and I am sure the Minister has himself noticed, on BBC and British Television, but we should certainly try to encourage a more particular appreciation of the larger world around us where our young people are concerned.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Sir, the Ministry of Culture certainly has great responsibilities to discharge. On the one hand, it will have to

Column: 629

actively propagate a multi-racial culture and values of our people. On the other hand, it will have to raise the cultural quality of our people, their thoughts and character, in order to cultivate them to be people of good quality. This is not an easy task.

    Over the last few years, the Ministry of Culture has actually put in some effort in the promotion of various healthy cultural and artistic activities, such as the holding of public art exhibitions, the organising of public music concerts for the people and so on, to popularise artistic tastes and appreciation among the people. Radio and TV Singapore have also put forward a number of good programmes such as students' debating forums which help them to have a better understanding of and interest in current affairs and in academic studies. There have also been programmes like News Magazine, Children's Magazine, Daily Digest which are meaningful as well as educative. However, the number of such healthy programmes is too small. On the contrary, there is a greater number of nonsensical programmes which outweigh and nullify the influence of healthy programmes. In spite of the cultural contribution of the Ministry of Culture, there exist in our society also undesirable cultural pieces in the form of sensual, erotic, monstrous and phantasmic films, literature and pictures which exert a great degenerating and corrupting effect on our people, our youth in particular. and turning them into a weak lot. So for the future of our youths, our task now is to strengthen our healthy cultural force in order to promote and popularise healthy and artistic cultural activities so as to help them recognise their values and be able to distinguish the good from the bad. This will benefit them in their life-time.

    Among our youths, there is a sign of decadence. It is mainly because of the fact that some of them have been affected by the bad habits of Western youths. They take to a life of enjoyment, are easy-going and are not interested in our healthy cultural and artistic performances. This is a very urgent task pertaining to the pattern of thought of our youths that is facing the Ministry of Culture

Column: 630

and all of us. Obviously, the main task of the Ministry of Culture is how to face this challenge, how to help the young to be receptive to good culture and to rectify their errors and wrong thinking and to recognise which type of culture will bring them beneficial influence. In this way, we can mould our youths into a great force in our nation building and cultural development.

    Sir, I would now like to advance four suggestions to the Minister for his reference, to help policy formulation. First, this concerns the work of raising the consciousness of our people; in other words, national consciousness. What kind of plan, of organized activities is the Ministry of Culture going to take in order to promote our cultural quality? Second, will the Minister consider reducing the rental charged for the use of our National Theatre, the Victoria Memorial Hall, or reducing the entertainment duty on certain performances in order to help more artistes, both local and foreign, to perform in Singapore? These will include pugilistics, music and concert shows. At the moment, because of the high charges, interested organisers do not find it easy to organise such performances. So our people are deprived of more opportunities to enjoy such performances of a higher standard.

    Third, whether the Ministry has taken note of the many undesirable, phantasmic and erotic literature and pictures being put on sale in the streets. Last year I asked the Minister about this and he promised to look into it. One year has passed. How is it that this sort of thing is still going on? Is it because the staff in the Ministry of Culture are not efficient in their work, or is it because the staff concerned are not willing to shoulder their responsibilities?

    Fourth, what plans the Ministry of Culture has in the promotion of various community cultures and artistic activities? All these traditional many-splendoured cultures and arts should be propagated because they will help to enrich our cultural heritage and, at the same time, give us a good image internationally, besides boosting our tourism.

Column: 631



3.00 p.m.

    Mr L. P. Rodrigo (Serangoon Gardens): Sir, one of the hazards of being on good terms with the Member for Katong is that in allowing him to speak ahead of you on a head of expenditure such as this, you find that there is not much else to say. I quite realise that in a debate, repetition is inevitable. But in this remarkable incident, if I were to speak it might appear that the Member for Katong had stolen my notes last night and formulated the address which he has so ably presented this afternoon! So I have nothing more to add but to concur with all that the Member has said in regard to policy and to support him fully in his suggestions.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Sir, what has the Government done in the encouragement of cultural development, and what exactly is the Government's cultural policy? These are questions people often ask. Frankly I do not know the answer and I do not think many do. Indeed, doubts have just been expressed by the Member for Katong. Out of the total Main Estimates of $44.7 million, $23.1 million or more than 50% goes to the maintenance of the Broadcasting Department; and out of the total Development Estimates of $14.7 million. $8.5 million or close to 60% goes towards the further expansion of the Broadcasting Department. Figuratively it would appear that the Ministry of Culture is primarily concerned with the promotion of TV culture. If this is the case then, rather than mislead the people, I would suggest that a more appropriate title for the Ministry would be the Ministry of Broadcasting!

    If we are serious about cultural development and firmly believe it to be a vital part of nation-building, a lot more effort will have to be put in. First of all, let us identify the correct direction of development so that hopefully we could in time, have a distinctive culture that we can truly call our own. I do appreciate this may take years, if not generations, but then the foundation has to be laid. During the past 10 years we have done little to patronise the arts. They have

Column: 632

been left largely on their own. Until today we do not have a decent art gallery. Notwithstanding the small size of our Republic. I agree with the Member for Jurong when he spoke recently during the debate on the Budget that there is a need and we could easily support a national academy of arts and music. But today the learning of arts and music remains largely the privilege of the affluent few, as only they can afford the high tuition fees. Artists have no place in our society. This is reflected by the fact that seldom do we see them featured in our National Day Honours list.

    The Hon. Minister for Culture and the Deputy Prime Minister are frequently seen patronising Cantonese operas performed by visiting artistes, and yet we ban street wayangs which surely are much more relevant to our cultural heritage than the imported operas. I am all for economic development, but I would hate to see all Singaporeans becoming economic animals lacking the ability to appreciate the finer things in life which are not necessarily obtainable with money alone. I do not profess to be a man of culture or to know very much about culture, unlike my Hon. Friend, the Member for Katong. But to me, quality of life in a society should not be measured simply in terms of per capita income, number of TV sets owned, heights of buildings or the number of chimney stacks at industrial estates. These materialistic things are important and vital for our survival, but so is the spiritual aspect of life. Grantinq that economic development should be given top priority in the context of Singapore, and we should be thankful that the Government has done well in this direction, however I suspect there is generally a misconception that the promotion of culture has no relevance to economic growth. We are doing well in tourism. I think we can do better if there are more activities of a cultural nature.

    There are many examples around the world where promotion in cultural activities has directly and indirectly benefited tourism. Take, for example, the very successful Edinburgh Festival and the National Eisteddfod held in Britain and indeed many

Column: 633

other similar Festivals held annually in other countries are major tourist attractions. Sir, our own excellent efforts in turning the Republic into a Garden City have helped in no small measure to draw tourists to Singapore. This leads me to think that if we promote Culture with the same heart and soul as we put into the promotion of Horticulture, I feel sure that the Nation will derive tremendous benefits both spiritually and economically.

    Sir, with rapid urban redevelopment our City will soon lose many of our traditional characteristics. Has it ever occurred to the Ministry that before the bulldozers move into any one area, it would perhaps be a good idea to systematically capture either on films or canvas personally I would prefer canvas so that our local painters can be commissioned to do the jobs scenes that may soon be no more so that the generations coming after us will at least have some idea as to the environment of their forefathers. Sir, in many cities in the world permanent open-air display centres are provided for artists -painters and sculptors. The provision of similar facilities at the pedestrian mall in Orchard Road is at present under active consideration by the Urban Redevelopment Authority, but strangely enough the idea did not originate from the Ministry of Culture. Surely there must be many other ways to promote cultural activities which will not cost the Government too much if we are too concerned about money.

    Dr Chiang Hai Ding (Ulu Pandan): Sir, after listening to the Member for Katong, who made a very plaintive speech. I suspect that the solution to his problem may not lie in transferring wine from one kind of bottle to another but in inviting the Minister to drink the wine that he offers year in and year out, always under the present circumstances with such good spirit.

    Singapore is located at an international cross-road. It has a relatively open society and is therefore subjected to many cultural influences. Our people are regularly reminded by the political leadership of our need for "cultural ballast".

Column: 634



    We have furthermore, in the last decade and a half, literally transformed the life-style of our people. More than half live in high-rise flats instead of kampong-type environments. We are now also engaged in manufacturing. industry, shipbuilding and repairing, banking and other services, whereas previously our people were essentially traders.

    In the process we have become collectively richer. Our Gross Domestic Product at factor cost rose four times from $3,043.4 million in 1965 to $12,831.7 million in 1975. Our per capita GDP in 1965 was $1,566. By 1975 it also rose almost four times to $5,917.

    Mr Speaker, we have an economic policy which, the Member for Jalan Kayu has just told us, is eminently successful. We have a labour policy, a foreign policy, a defence policy, even a policy for sports. In education, as this House was reminded, so forcefully reminded, we have policies galore.

    But what is our cultural policy? What are our plans and objectives? Seventeen years have passed since we formed the government, ten since we became independent. Where are we now?

    Are we culturally an identifiable people? Are there, for example, songs that we, or our children, can all sing? Or dances that they can all enjoy? Are there any particular art forms that we have consciously promoted for our people's appreciation?

    I am sure that Singaporeans are not merely people sporting short hair, most of whom should not smoke and many of whom are illiterate in two languages.

    It pains me to propose a cut of $ 10/- from the Minister. He needs, or his Ministry needs, every cent it can get.

    I know that we cannot measure culture in quantitative terms. But I ask Members to join me to look at how much we have spent on Culture since we became independent ten years ago. Through the courtesy of the staff of Parliament every Member should have on

Column: 635

his chair an Appendix (See cols 711-2) setting out the percentage of the Ordinary and Development Estimates that this House voted for Culture since 1965. If you look at the figures in the Appendix*, it will bear out the limited financial allocations that we have made to Culture, In the Ordinary Estimates the percentage allocated to Culture of the total fell steadily from a high of 3.9% in 1965 to 1.5% in 1975/76. The figure proposed for 1976/77 is 1.4%.

    In the Development Estimates the story is about the same except for a bump in 1972-75. Otherwise, once again we see a decline from 1.5% in 1965 to 0.55% in 1975/76. The figure proposed for 1976/77 is 0.56%.
